qas.question: When did de Sabbata and Gasperini write?
What theory came after the quark structure of matter?
Understanding electrical structure has lead to important advances in what field?
Who described particles as quantum excitations?

context: There is an entire literature concerning the "structure of matter", ranging from <b1_0>the "electrical structure"<b1_0/> in <b0_0>the early 20th century<b0_0/>, to the more recent "quark structure of matter", introduced today with the remark: Understanding the quark structure of matter has been one of the most important advances in <b2_0>contemporary physics<b2_0/>.[further explanation needed] In this connection, physicists speak of matter fields, and speak of particles as "quantum excitations of a mode of the matter field". And here is a quote from <b3_0>de Sabbata and Gasperini<b3_0/>: "With the word "matter" we denote, in this context, the sources of the interactions, that is spinor fields (like quarks and leptons), which are believed to be the fundamental components of matter, or scalar fields, like the Higgs particles, which are used to introduced mass in a <b4_0>gauge theory<b4_0/> (and that, however, could be composed of more fundamental fermion fields)."[further explanation needed]
